fire-knowledge/irpg.html.title: IRPG
fire-knowledge/irpg.html.description:
Everyone should have an Incident Response Pocket Guide (IRPG)Current version (2025) is pink. Older versions are still acceptable.
Cheapest online vendor: Curtis - IRPG, 2025 Edition
Digital version: IRPG App (iOS & Android) -- This is a backup, not a substitute for your physical IRPG.You must memorize verbatim the back cover of your IRPG: Keep informed on fire weather conditions and forecasts. Know what your fire is doing at all times. Base all actions on current and expected behavior of the fire. Identify escape routes and safety zones, and make them known. Post lookouts when there is possible danger. Be alert. Keep calm. Think clearly. Act decisively. Maintain prompt communications with your forces, your supervisor, and adjoining forces. Give clear instructions and be sure they are understood. Maintain control of your forces at all times. Fight fire aggressively, having provided for safety first. Fire not scouted and sized up. In country not seen in daylight. Safety zones and escape routes not identified. Unfamiliar with weather and local factors influencing fire behavior. Uninformed on strategy, tactics, and hazards. Instructions and assignments not clear. No communication link with crewmembers or supervisor. Constructing line without safe anchor point. Building fireline downhill with fire below. Attempting frontal assault on fire. Unburned fuel between you and the fire. Cannot see main fire; not in contact with someone who can. On a hillside where rolling material can ignite fuel below. Weather becoming hotter and drier. Wind increases and / or changes direction. Getting frequent spotfires across line. Terrain and fuels make escape to safety zones difficult. Taking a nap near fireline.

headers.heading: 10 Standard Firefighting Orders
18 Watch Out Situations

military-knowledge/army-values-&-general.title: Army Values & General Orders
military-knowledge/army-values-&-general.description:
You are expected to have these memorized.
Loyalty
Duty
Respect
Selfless Service
Honor
Integrity
Personal Courage
Notice this spells out the acronym: LDRSHIP(see page 1:1 in the PDF linked above)
I will guard everything within the limits of my post and quit my post only when properly relieved.
I will obey my special orders and perform all my duties in a military manner.
I will report violations of my special orders, emergencies, and anything not covered in my instruction, to the Commander of the Relief.
The General Orders are fixated on guarding a military post. "Special orders" are any other order issued to you, such as drill orders, Emergency State Active Duty (ESAD) orders, etc.

military-knowledge/chain-of-command-expe.title: Chain of Command Expectations
military-knowledge/chain-of-command-expe.description:
[Related: Chain of Command Diagram & US Army Ranks and Insignia]Summary: Always communicate with your ASL / SL first. Never jump the Chain of Command ie "go around" your direct leadership. The Open Door Policy exists.Military organizations are strictly hierarchical. Aside from rank, a Service Member is subject to the hierarchy of their "Chain of Command".The "Chain of Command" is a strategy for: distributing orders and information down the hierarchy : "pusing out" information organizing information as it moves up the hierarchy : "pushing up" information The fundamental idea is that you are a "link" in the chain that strictly communicates with the level above (your direct supervisor) and the level below (your direct direct subordinates, if any).A "squad" is a small team of soldiers.As a member of 3rd PLT / 3rd SQD your direct supervisors are the Assistant Squad Leader (ASL) and Squad Leader (SL). Unless explicitly assigned, there is no one below you in the hierarchy.The ASL and SL of the squad are directly responsible for the remaining squad members (you). As a member of the squad, you will most often receive orders from the ASL if not the SL.The orders you receive from the squad-level leadership were likely passed down from platoon-level leadership.A "platoon" is a collection of 2-4 squads.The direct supervisor of a SL is the Platoon Sergeant (PSG). This person is typically a high-ranking Non-Commissioned Officer (NCO).The PSG works closely with the Platoon Leader (PL) who is typically a (commissioned) Officer.The differences between NCOs and Officers are outside the scope of this article. Just know that Officers always outrank NCOs.If you have a question / issue / request, always go through the ASL. If they can't immediately field your inquiry, the ASL will talk with the SL. From there the SL might talk with the PSG and so on.I call this "pushing up" information. For example a 1003 form must be pushed up to the Command Officer of RSD for approval.As you move up the Chain of Command, the scope of responsibility at each level expands. A high-level leader doesn't need to know about the specifics of your particular issue. It is up to your direct leadership to distill the information to what is necessary.By going through the ASL & SL, issues can be solved at the lowest level. Perhaps your problem is part of a larger trend that can be solved as a batch. Trust in your direct leadership to digest your situation and present it properly to higher levels of leadership if necessary.When your SL receives information / an order from the PSG and forwards it to the Squad that is "pushing out" information.Don't do this.Let's say you know high-level leader X has the power to fix your particular issue, so you communicate with that leader directly to get it fixed -- you are wrong.This action undermines your direct leadership by keeping them in the dark about your situation. It also implies that you do not trust your direct leadership or believe them to be incompetent. It is disrespectful to "go around" leaders in your Chain of Command.Furthermore, the nitty-gritty of your particular situation is not the concern of high-level leaders and is likely a waste of their time.Whenever possible, address your issues at the lowest possible level (within our squad).Let's say an issue arises that can't be solved despite your best effort to use the Chain of Command. You always have the option to speak with a high-level leader by invoking their "Open Door Policy".
Per AR-600-20, "an open door policy allows members of the command to present facts, concerns, and problems of a personal or professional nature or other issues that the Soldier has been unable to resolve."I want to emphasize this policy is for issues that you have been "unable to resolve" by normal means. Maybe you feel that your direct leader is cutting you off from higher-level leaders for unjust reasons or the issue is a direct result of their wrongful actions -- consider using the Open Door Policy to get help because the Chain of Command is now broken above you.Again, try to resolve problems at the lowest level. Trust your leadership. Only after that fails should you consider using the Open Door Policy.

military-knowledge/drill-and-ceremony-ba.title: Drill and Ceremony Basics
military-knowledge/drill-and-ceremony-ba.description:
Position of Attention https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8De7O691yjcParade Rest At Ease Rest
https://youtu.be/onGybrxXSIs?si=Bj7LLm9aeoPMTT0PThese follow the format of: Preparatory Command - Command of ExecutionLeft - Face Right - Face About - Face
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0QP6_5Ky4QColumn Left - March
https://youtu.be/emt8dzkU0l4?si=4OZ-5ydb9mvklQGR pivot on your right foot to turn left "march" should be called on the left foot step, allowing you one more step before you pivot on right step Column Right - March
https://youtu.be/E-HHz0pk_xk?si=oeYiqz4MwMlglncp pivot on your right foot to turn left "march" should be called on the right foot step, allowing you one more step before you pivot on left step

rsd-info-links/email-accounts-explained..title: Email Accounts Explained
rsd-info-links/email-accounts-explained..description:
SMs should have access to two email accounts.If you lack access to either, notify your SL.Each account serves different purposes:This is a state issued Microsoft 365 account. It is your primary email for communication using Outlook.This account also grants you access to:
Unit SharePoint page: CSG - Rattlesnake Support Detachment (RSD) Repository of documents for admin / ops / logistics / training
2025 Yearly Training Calendar
VIPER app Power App for tracking personnel / issued gear / training certs If you get an account access error, reach out to your SL for access. This is a state issued Google account. Do not use it for email communication.Log in every <90 days or you will lose access.
This accounts exists to grant you access to GoCSG: GoCSG is a platform for tracking missions and SM profiles / orders. Use it to retrieve your orders for drill GoCSG will be phased out in the coming months. Archive your certs now.

rsd-info-links/name-tapes-and-patches.ht.title: Name Tapes and Patches
rsd-info-links/name-tapes-and-patches.ht.description:
Current (as of 2025) CSG name tapes are black with silver-grey text and AR670-1 compliant.LASTNAME - Name Tape Enter your last name in ALL CAPS when ordering You need at least two x1 for your blouse x1 for your patrol cap
CALIFORNIA - Branch Tape You need at least one for your blouse
CSG Unit Patch You need at least one for your blouse

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
